Title: Collapse function for block of code and comments hiding
description:
1. Collapse function should be able to collapse block of code between "{" 
and "}" into a single line looking something like "{ ... }", displayed in 
different color or style. 
2. As an addition to bracket matching, there should a way to display an 
vertical line starting just under opening "{" going all the way down to 
matching closing "}", if one exists. This should be configurable in terms of 
color and turning on/off.
3. For the comments, there should be a button which would either display the 
comments or hide them. When hidden, special marker would be displayed one 
character space left from where the comments were and this marker should take 
only one character space, or none if possible. It should be like the comments 
in MS Excel. 
4. When 3. combined with 1., there should be another configuration item, that 
would turn on/off displaying comments in collapsed block of code.

This would make handling large/complex pieces of code much easier. If code can 
be also printed as it is displayed, it would be great.

Title: [plan item] Improve support for opening workspaces
description:
Improve support for opening workspaces. Many users use multiple workspaces as 
a way to keep their different projects or work items separate. Currently, this 
requires launching Eclipse multiple times with different command line 
arguments, which is not particularly convenient for users. Moreover, when the 
command line argument is not specified, the workspace location defaults to a 
directory inside where the code for Eclipse is installed. Eclipse should 
improve how workspaces get opened, use a user-specific default workspace 
location more suitable for shared multi-user Eclipse installs, and facilitate 
switching between workspaces. [Platform Core, Platform UI] [Themes: User 
experience]

Title: [Decorators] ILightweigthDecorator should be able to decorate multiple quadrants
description:
Current the definition of a lightweight decorator in XML limits the decorator to
one quadrant (e.g. top-left/bottom-left/top-right/bottom-right). There are many
cases where a single instance of a lightweight decorator must decorate more
(e.g. example a Team provider that adds checkout/checked in and read/write)
decorations.

We should allow a light weight decorator more flexibility for decorating
multiple quadrants.

The current workaround is to create two lightweight decorators.

Title: Hard to pin down a console
description:
I usually run with the "Show when program writes to standard out" option 
turned ON. But sometimes I run more than one program at a time so the console 
view flips quickly back and forth between the two programs as they produce 
output. While this is going on, you can't select a different console to look 
at because Eclipse will immediately flip back to the active one.

I try pressing Pin Console, and it does temporarily stop the flipping. I can 
switch to a different view that overlays Console, and Console will come up to 
the top as soon as there is output. So far so good.

However when I select another console using the Display Selected Console 
dropdown view menu, the Pin Console button is unselected and it starts 
flipping back and forth again.

Enhancement #1: Leave the Pin Console on. Selecting another console should 
switch to that console but leave it pinned so it doesn't switch back.

If I click in the Debug view, the console window changes to the output of the 
process I clicked on. This is very nice, especially when you have more than a 
couple processes running with similar names (making the dropdown hard to use). 
Unfortunately it doesn't work when Pin Console is selected.

Enhancement #2: Make clicking in the Debug view work just like the Display 
Selected Console dropdown - switch to the selected console whether or not Pin 
Console is enabled. If it's enabled, stay there and leave it enabled.

Just to clarify, I'm suggesting that the "Show when program writes to standard 
out/error" option continue to make the console view visible and on top of its 
stack when there is output. If Pin Console is OFF, it should also switch to 
the process that had output like it does now. But if Pin Console is ON, it 
should leave the currently displayed console alone.

These two changes will make the console window much easier to pin down, and 
I'm hoping they're not very difficult to implement.

Title: [Properties View] DCR: PageBookView should support shared pages
description:
There are valid cases where two+ IEditorParts would like to use the same shared 
page as their contributed page to the Properties View, and in our case, the GEF 
palette.

For the properties view, returning a custom propertysheet page means that your 
Table widget is unique to the editor.  So, if the user resizes the columns in 
instance 1, and then switches to instance 2 of the same editor type, the 
columns have to be resized again.

For the GEF palette, shared behavior would be the expansion of drawers and 
other UI state which has no reason to be instance based.

We need this behavior for GEF 3.0, so if it isn't implemented, we will have to 
implement it.  But, if we do it, propertysheet clients would not benefit.  I'd 
be happy to commit the fix.

Title: [SSH2] implement preferred ssh version support

ideally we could provide a more dynamic protocol discovery and switching:

1 only, 1, 2, 2 only

Our default would be 2 but we would allow users to change.

This essentially means that the SSH2 plugin will handle delegation to the ssh1 
connection method based on the servers return code. But then, you really only 
want to check the server once and not on every connection.

Title: need to support empty partition
description: from bug 49212, comment one: I'd appreciate some indicatation that this problem will be addressed or if it is considered a feature one must adapt to. For some time I've been considering just replacing the ContentAssistant, but I see you are in the process of generalizing it, and I would rather stick with it if possible. Other problems that have been in ContentAssistant for quite awhile and need fixing: 1. Auto assist should not be triggered when a backspace character is typed. This can be very annoying. At the very least, this should be optional behavior. 2. Assist is too naive about the nature of partitions. It is easy to see the effect in an XML file. If the cursor is here: | and the user types an auto-assist trigger for text partitions, code assist comes up. But if the cursor is here: | and the user types the same character, code assist is not triggered. This is because (prior to 3.0) the caret position would be considered to be in the partition, and the trigger valid in text is not valid in tags. Users constantly encounter this in flowed text, where very often the cursor is "pushing" an end tag. There are two basic kinds of partition: delimited and undelimited. In a delimited partition, the caret position at the partition offset is not logically inside the partition. Using the type of the preceding partition, if any, to select the activation characters is often a better choice (if the preceding paritition is undelimited) and in any event not worse. The current logic is like: Get partition at position. Use type of partition to select content assist processor Call processor to get auto activation characters I would like it to be: Get partition at position. If position == partition offset and partition type is delimited and position > 0 then Get partition at position-1. Use type of partition to select content assist processor Call processor to get auto activation characters The ability to determine whether a partition is delimited would be useful in a number of other contexts, as well. This solution would depend on a fix for the current bug.

Title: No specific feedback if commit fails
description:
I did the following:

- Modified the same file (managed by CVS) on two computers in such a way that
CVS could not automatically merge the changes.

- Committed the changes on machine A.

- Performed an update on machine B.

- Didn't realize that I needed to manually merge the affected file, so I tried
to commit machine B's project to the repository.

- This failed (becuase the affected file had not been merged), but the error
message that I got just said that the CVS commit failed without indicating the
reason.

What I expected:

When a CVS commit fails becuase a file needs to be merged manually and this has
not been performed, I would expect to receive a specific message identifying the
file that needs merging along with indicating that the specified file needs to
be manually merged.  Bonus points if there is a one-click way to open the
identified file so I can fix it. :-)

Title: Update should fix timestamps when there are no differences
description:
Would it be possible to enhance CVS update to fix the timestamp of a file that
isn't different from the repository (no differences or only pseudo-conflicts) so
that it doesn't show as an outgoing change?  This is what WinCVS does, and I
find it to be a very useful/convenient feature.

In Debugland, we'd like to present the user with relevant views when they switch 
between debugged languages (represented as contexts). As such, we're providing 
support for "context view bindings" which allow contributors to specify which 
views should be made available when a context is active.

It's possible that we need to open a view and it will appear on the same stack 
as a currently visible, applicable view. In this case, we want the newly opened 
view to appear underneath the currently visible one. For example, if you have 
the Variables view open and visible and then you switch to the "Java Debugging" 
context, the Display view will be opened on top of the Variables view. With this 
API, we'll be able to open the Display view with minimal visual disruption for 
the user.

Title: [Preferences] Autorefresh polling preference presentation
description:
Build 20040127

The way the polling preference is presented makes it look like the autorefresh feature relies on 
polling to do its job. Unless things have changed since Jed wrote it, however, autorefresh normally 
doesn't poll at all, but relies on natives for "interrupt-driven" updates.

The polling preference should somehow let the user know that it will only be used if the native 
notifications fail. Ideally, the autorefresh plug-in should know whether or not the native support is 
there, so it should be able to tell the user whether or not the preference will have any effect. 
Maybe, the preference could even be hidden if the autorefresh plug-in detects that it won't be 
used? At the very least, though, there should be text there (even if it has to be verbose) to inform 
the user of the setting's implications.

Title: Preferences are inaccessible without loading the Plugin runtime class
description:
We have a situation where we would like access to the Preference Store in a way
that does not require the loading or even the existence of a Plugin. Ideally,
the functionality would be exposed in a way that we could (at least) look up
existing preferences using a plugin-id and preference name. We have a *nice to
have* feature where we could automatically migrate preferences from existing
workspaces in new versions of the product. However, refactoring and redesigns
from the previous version have motivated the change of plugin names and
preference names. We have the necessary framework to invoke the migration, but
we need access to the existing values and ideally we would be able to transfer
and persist those values for new plugins.

Title: Hardcoded "links" folder may be not a good design.
description:
I've been using Eclipse and the "links" folder for quite a while and it has 
proven to be an excellent feature.  But now I am starting to develop in Linux 
where the Eclipse driver is located in a shared directory owned by the root - 
each user launches it specifying a different workspace with the -data option.

The problem with this configuration (which appears to be really reasonable) is 
that there is no simple way of allowing each user to set the plugins the link 
files in the links folder should point to.

What about having the links folder defined as an argument (such as the 
workspace)?  Even better, to have an option to define more than one workspace 
(the order in the command line would define the precedence in case of 
duplicated plugin.  This could be something like

./eclipse -links "/home/user1/links1;/lib/commonPlugins"

Title: Apply Patch dialog doesn't initialize file browse dialog
description:
Build 20040129

1. The first time you bring up the Apply Patch dialog, the patches file location field initializes to 
empty.
2. The first time you press the Browse button, it opens a (native) file selection dialog initialized to 
the Eclipse install directory.
3. After applying a patch, subsequent invocations of the Apply Patch dialog will initialize the file 
location field to the location of the last patch.
4. Pressing the Browse button, however, still initializes to the Eclipse install directory.

In step 2, the file selection dialog should be initialized to the user's home directory instead of the 
Eclipse install directory. User's generally don't (and shouldn't) store patch files in that location.
In step 4, the file selection dialog should be initialized to the directory of the patch that's shown in 
the text field.

Title: Launch view should not track view open close during perspective reset
description:
The launch view currently tracks which "managed views" the user has manually 
opened and closed in order to not automatically override anything the user has 
done. This information is cleared when the user resets the perspective.

However, the launch view continues to listen to part open/close notifications 
sent during the reset and will add these back to the collections. When the 
workbench provides start/finish style notifications for perspective reset, we'll 
be able to remove our listener when the reset starts and add it again when it 
finishes (or just wait until the finish notification to clear the cache).

Title: fix partioner to handle angle brackets in attribute values.
description: The partitioner prevents the formatter from correctly formatting elements that have a '>' inside an attribute value. Title: cvs client is creating empty directories and then pruning them.
description:
The eclipse cvs client is creating directories which contain no resources and at
the end of the cvs process pruning them.  Cygwin and other cvs clients operate
in a smarter manner and never create those directories.

This poses efficiency problems when there exist large numbers of empty
directories.  Also in the case where an update fails empty directories are left
over which should have been pruned.

input task)

Title: Allow binding filenames to compare extensions
description:

extension point. This is to allow binding an editor to a specific filename --
e.g. "xxx.xml, yyy.xml". For the same reasons that this was added to the editors
extension it is now also needed in compare to associate compare editors with
those specific filenames.

description:

Title: Strange message in console upon startup
description:
Build: I-20040420

Not sure if this is Update or PDE-build, but it happens upon startup so Update 
is a good place to start.

to the console (i.e. nothing in the log).

Unable to find feature.xml in directory 
d:\test\eclipse\features\org.eclipse.pde.container.feature_1.0.0


First of all, this is the name of the fake feature that PDE generates to house 
the plug-ins the user is exporting.  We create this feature in our own 
metadata area and delete it at the end.

So the questions are:
1. How/Why/When is it detected by Update?
2. How is Update looking for it in the root Eclipse install at the next 
startup?

I remember that at some point Pascal collaborated with Christophe when coming 
up with pde-build story, and Pascal actually builds a site to house the 
features being built.  He does so by calling Update's State API.  So maybe 
these calls cause Update to think that there is a new feature in the root 
install.

Title: CVS synchronization slow for "-d" option
description:
We have a project with many attic files and directories. Starting with M8,
sync'ing really takes long. I have a burst for about 5-10 sec. at the beginning
of the sync process (approx. 400K read/write net traffic and close to 100% CPU
on the local machine). Then net traffic drops to 1-2k (both read and write)
while local CPU is idle (0%) and remote cvs is at approx. 1% CPU. At this state,
the remaining sync process takes approx. 5 minutes.
I figured this has something to do with attic files/directories. When I uncheck
the option "Fetch absent or new directories while updating", the project
synchronizes in 5-10 sec (the traffic burst mentioned above) as compared to 5+
minutes with the option set.
This happens with both cvs-ssh2 and pserver (tested on the same project). I
didn't experience this in earlier 3.0 builds or any of the 2.x builds (tested
with both cvs-ssh2 and pserver). Also, my colleague using M8 GTK on Linux has
not reported any performance issues.

Title: XML include syntax not fully supported by Ant editor?
description:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<!DOCTYPE project [
    <!ENTITY properties SYSTEM "file:properties.xml">
]>

causes an error in the ant editor which complains about not being able to 
find "file:properties.xml" (FileNotFoundException).

Fixed by removing "file:" but ant editor should (?) recognise the file prefix 
as not being part of the filename.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<!DOCTYPE project [
    <!ENTITY properties SYSTEM "properties.xml">
]>

works fine.

file: syntax works with ant 1.5.3 and 1.6.1 and is as used in Java Development 
with Ant.

Title: Hard coded colour making text unreadable
description:
The popup menu to select an editor (used when there are many editor windows
open) is hard coded to a background colour of white.  This is fine if you use a
typical text colour of black.  It's very bad if you use an inverted colour
display scheme, as you end up with pale text on a white background, which is
effectively unreadable (especially on a laptop screen).  

The correct behaviour should likely be something along the lines of using the
platforms default tooltip colour, or at least the default text editor background
colour (note, that haven't seen any other popup menus in eclipse with this problem).

The offending code would appear to be in
org.eclipse.ui.internal.presentations.EditorList , in the constructor:

    public EditorList(Shell parent, int shellStyle, int treeStyle) {
        super(parent, shellStyle, treeStyle);
        setBackgroundColor(new Color(parent.getDisplay(), 255, 255, 255));
    }

<RANT>I know I don't need to remind you eclipse folks, as you've done a
commendable job so far;  for everyone else out there (especially web designers):
 if you 'must' hardcode a background colour, you __must__ hard code the
forground colour as well!!!!</RANT>  

Thank you :)

Title: List features not enabled via command API
description: The API lets you list features that are enabled in the configuration, but not those installed in sites that the config knows about that are not enabled. This can be seen in the Product Configuration dialog when you select the disabled features toggle. Use case is an ISV trying to install their software on a target product who checks for their pre-reqs up front. They can only see configured features so they say no - we can't install or worse, install the missing features again. If they could list disabled features then after the first search they could ask again - is the feature there but disabled? The API should either add an option to the current command, or a new command. Maybe the implementation should be a list all features and each includes an attribute (prefix or suffix) that identifies state. Maybe it should be: -command allFeatures I don't see this as an option on the API doc page: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-update- home/doc/working/documentation/standalone_update.html

]>

</target>

</project>

Title: Incorrect Placement and Persistance of Error Icons in Syncronize View
description:
Build id: 200405201226.

When a compile error is introduced into a class that has an outgoing change, the
package and folders show the red X error icon. However, folder/packages in that
project that come before that file also incorrectly show the red X error icon.
Furthermore, once the compile error is fixed, these folders/packages still show
the icon when the corrected file's package does not.

Steps that I used to reproduce (may be a simpler way):
1. Create a bogus() method in an easily accessible class.
2. In a class in a project that has multiple changes, and it is in at least the
second package that has changes, call this bogus() method.
3. Delete the bogus() method from the first class.
4. Error icons are displayed on the project + package of the second class, as
well as the package that comes before this second class.
5. Remove the call from the bogus() method from the second class.
6. The error icon on the second class's package goes away, but the project +
other package error icon remains, even after a forced synchronize.

Title: Build delta frequency
description: Let me tell a story about two friends, the PRE_BUILD and POST_BUILD resource change events. In Eclipse 2.1, PRE_BUILD fired before autobuilds, and POST_BUILD fired after autobuilds. Neither of them ran before manual builds. In the last month, we decided that PRE_BUILD and POST_BUILD must also occur before and after manual builds. This is because project references are now computed dynamically, and the project reference providers need an opportunity to let us know when they have changed *before* any kind of building happens. Otherwise, the build won't happen in the correct order. So, as of last week, PRE_BUILD occurred before the first build of an operation, and POST_BUILD happened at the end of any operation in which a build occurred. By "end of operation" here, I mean when our core operation depth counter reaches zero. It turns out, of course, that workspace operations can overlap each other in Eclipse 3.0. This means that the operation depth might not reach zero until much later, at the end of an operation that began before the build completed. If the overlapping operation did not have a scheduling rule on the workspace root, then a failure would occur if a POST_BUILD listener modified a resource outside the scope of that operation's rule. See bug 62927 for an exact test case. Last night, I attempted to release a fix for this. My fix was to fire POST_BUILD at the first "endOperation" after the PRE_BUILD event. I.e., the next time the operation depth is decremented after the PRE_BUILD. This fix was short-sighted. It meant that POST_BUILD would now occur *during* the build, the first time any builder modified a resource (causing a nested operation to begin and end). In addition, this fix caused the JDT core test suites to fail. Now, we reach the dramatic conclusion of the story. 'Twas the night before M9, I am about to leave on vacation, very few people are around, and I have to perform 11th hour changes to when resource change events occur. I cannot come up with a reasonable rule for exactly when POST_BUILD should occur. It must happen after PRE_BUILD, and immediately before the last time that the thread that performed PRE_BUILD is going to release the scheduling rule required to perform POST_BUILD. Essentially what I need to do is maintain the operation depth pre thread, and then perform POST_BUILD when the operation depth of the thread that performed PRE_BUILD is about to go lower than the the depth it was at when PRE_BUILD occurred. Then I began thinking: How would I explain this story to other components? It feels that the rule for when PRE_BUILD and POST_BUILD is now too complex for anyone to reasonably understand. So, I have opted for a simpler solution, at least for M9. I am now doing PRE_BUILD immediately prior to *every* API build call (IWorkspace.build, IProject.build), and POST_BUILD immediately after every build. This means more of these events are occurring in the scenario where a group of projects are built one after another in an operation. This may have performance implications. I have run all platform core and JDT core test suites, without failures. It looks like it will do for M9. We can discuss next week if this makes sense as the final answer for 3.0.
